RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
In  India,  the  total  power  generation  capacity  available  to  the  grid  was  112,000 
megawatts (MW) as of 31 March 2004, comprising 29,500 MW of hydro, 77,910 MW of thermal, 
2,720 MW of nuclear, and 1,870 MW of wind.  State electricity boards (SEBs) own 62% of the 
total  installed  capacity,  the  central  sector  26%,  and  the  private  sector  12%.  As  of  31  March 
2004, the peak power deficit was about 11% (9,510 MW); the energy deficit about 7% (39,870 
gigawatt-hours [GWh]). As of 31 March 2003, per capita electricity consumption stood at about 
567 kilowatt-hours (kWh). About 84% of villages, but only about 31% of rural households, were 
electrified.  Quality  of  power  is  poor,  with  frequent  load  shedding  (rationing)  and  significant 
voltage  fluctuation.  This  undermines  industrial  competitiveness  and  severely  constrains 
economic growth. The power system comprises five interconnected electrical regions: northern, 
northeastern, eastern, western, and southern. The sector analysis is presented in Appendix 1.  
 
3. 
The Tenth Five-Year Plan (the 10th Plan) targets a high growth rate of 8% per year to 
sustain poverty reduction. The Government recognizes electricity as one of the key drivers for 
economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction,  and  has  set  the  target  of  providing  access  to  all 
households  by  2012.  To  meet  this  target  100,000  MW  of  new  generation  capacity  is  needed. 
Because natural energy resources are unevenly distributed and concentrated in a few pockets, 
new  generation  plants  such  as  hydropower  and  coal-fired  mine-mouth  plants  are  located  far 
away from the load centers. To ensure reliable and secured delivery of power from generation 
projects to end users, development of an adequate transmission system is vital.  
 
4. 
In India, transmission and distribution (T&D) losses are quite high compared with other 
countries. The world average T&D loss is about 10–15%, while India’s T&D loss as of 31 March 
2003  was  reported  to  be  about  33%.  However,  in  the  absence  of  adequate  metering 
arrangements,  especially  for  agricultural  consumers,  some  of  the  losses  were  treated  as 
agricultural  consumption.  The  actual  losses  are,  therefore,  thought  to  be  much  higher,  with 
some  SEBs  now  reporting  T&D  losses  as  high  as  45–55%.  The  major  reasons  for  such  high 
losses  are  pilferage  of  electricity  through  unauthorized  connections,  tampering  of  meters,  and 
technical losses originating from overloaded T&D networks. 
 
The  organization  of  the  power  sector  is  determined  by  the  country's  dual  political 
5. 
structure—all major issues affecting the sector require concurrent action by the central and state 
governments. The financial health of SEBs has become a matter of concern for governments. 
SEB losses have reached an alarming level of Rs330 billion, equivalent to about 1.5% of gross 
domestic product. The accumulation of electricity arrears to the central power utilities has grown 
to  over  Rs400  billion.  Thus,  poor  creditworthiness  of  SEBs  has  considerably  slowed  private 
sector  investing  despite  the  central  Government’s  enabling  and  encouraging  framework. 
Consequently,  the  Government  formulated  the  Accelerated  Power  Development  and  Reform 
Program  (Supplementary  Appendix  A)  to  introduce  reforms  at  the  distribution  level  with  an 
overall objective of reducing T&D losses to 15%. Implementation began in February 2000.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

National Transmission Grid 

 
7. 
POWERGRID,  established  as  the  central  transmission  utility  in  1989  and  fully 
operational in 1991, is responsible for developing and operating the national transmission grid 
spanning interstate and interregional transmission links, including load dispatch. Prior to 1991, 
central  sector  generating  companies  constructed  and  operated  the  transmission  facilities  to 
evacuate  power  from  their  power  plants  and  transmit  to  client  SEBs.  Therefore,  the  national 
transmission  grid  has  historically  evolved  in  an  unplanned  manner,  resulting  in  transmission 
bottlenecks  with  high  transmission  losses.  At  present,  transmission  links  within  each  electrical 
region (interstate) and especially between the five electrical regions are limited.1  
 
8. 
With  the  addition  of  100,000  MW  of  generation  capacity  by  2012,  the  transmission 
bottlenecks  will  worsen  and  transmission  losses  will  increase  unless  the  national  transmission 
grid is strengthened and expanded. In 2003, the Government enacted the Electricity Act, which 
includes provision of open transmission access to facilitate development of a national market for 
power trading. POWERGRID responded by formulating the National Transmission Development 
Plan (NTDP) to develop a robust and reliable national transmission grid to ensure smooth power 
flow within the whole power system (Appendix 2). To implement the NTDP, investments totaling 
up  to  $12.6  billion  over  8  years  are  needed,  including  from  the private sector and commercial 
cofinancing. 
 
9.

Development  Bank  (ADB)  can  help  bring  down  the  total  cost  of  funds  to  POWERGRID  and

Asian Development Bank Strategy for the Power Sector 

 
ADB's  strategy  for  the  power  sector2  is  in  synergy  with  the  10th  Plan  to  develop

distribution systems; (iv) providing institutional strengthening to implement reforms required by 
the Electricity Act 2003; (v) promoting private sector participation; and (vi) encouraging energy

11. 
ADB  has  provided  support  for  nationwide  sector  reforms  through  Power  Finance

To  overcome  transmission  bottlenecks,  ADB’s  assistance  is  focused  on  strengthening  the 
national  transmission  grid  through  POWERGRID.5  The  proposed  sector  loan  will  support  the 
development of the national transmission grid and introduce best practices that will lead to pro-
poor growth and poverty reduction consistent with ADB's country assistance strategy for India. 
 
ADB has supported state power sector reforms and stand-alone investments in Assam,

3. 

Lessons Learned 

 
13. 
ADB has conducted four project performance audit reports for energy projects in India, 
comprising  two  loans  for  thermal  power  stations,  one  loan  for  a  hydrocarbon  sector  program, 
and one loan for gas rehabilitation and expansion. Relevant lessons learned are (i) the need for 
ADB to be flexible and adaptable to changing conditions in India, (ii) land acquisition should be 
carried  out  expeditiously  to  minimize  implementation  delays,  (iii)  construction  contracts should 
be  properly  packaged  to  facilitate  implementation  and  coordination,  and  (iv)  loan  covenants 
should be appropriate.

A. 

Objective 

26. 
The  objective  is  to  help  strengthen  and  develop  India’s  national  transmission  grid. 
Development of the national transmission grid is important given the location of natural energy 
resources  and  load  centers  (para.  3).  The  national  transmission  grid,  comprising  765  kV  and 
400  kV  transmission  lines  and  associated  substations,  needs  to  be  strengthened  and 
augmented to improve system reliability, facilitate interstate and interregional power transfers by 
removing  transmission  bottlenecks,  reduce  transmission  losses,  facilitate  efficient  utilization  of 
existing  and  planned  power  plants,  and  facilitate  development  of  a  national  power  trading 
market  through  open  access  to  the  national  transmission  grid.  The  Project  Framework  is  in 
Appendix 5. 
 
27. 
The sector loan modality is justified as (i) POWERGRID's NDTP is a well-defined sector 
development plan that covers all the five regional grids; and (ii) the Electricity Act 2003 provides 
the enabling policy environment for wholesale competition, trading, and efficiency improvements 
in  the  Indian  power  sector.  POWERGRID  has  demonstrated  its  institutional  capacity  to 
implement sector loans.

C. 

State Transmission and Distribution  

8. 
The  organization  of  the  power  sector  is  determined  by  the  country's  dual  political 
structure, so that all major issues affecting the sector require concurrent action by the central 
and  state  governments.  SEBs  are  under  the  administrative  control  of  the  respective  state 
ministry  of  power  or  department  of  power.  SEBs  now  account  for  approximately  80%  of 
commercial electricity sales. However, most state governments use SEBs to provide low tariffs 
for  agricultural  and  residential  consumers,  and  to  provide  employment  to  attract  political 
support. The consolidated rate of return on net fixed assets of SEBs has been negative and is 
deteriorating rapidly due mainly to low agriculture tariff, low cost recovery, and high transmission 
and distribution (T&D) losses. 
 
The world average T&D loss is about 10–15%, while India’s T&D loss as of March 2003 
9. 
was  about  33%.  However,  in  the  absence  of  adequate  metering  arrangements, especially for 
agricultural consumers, part of the losses were treated as agricultural consumption. The actual 
losses are, therefore, thought to be much higher, with some SEBs now reporting T&D losses as 
high  as  45–55%.  The  major  reasons  for  such  high  losses  are  pilferage  of  energy  through 
unauthorized  connections  and  tampering  of  meters,  and  technical  losses  originating  from 
overloaded distribution networks. 
 
The  financial  health  of  SEBs  has  become  a  matter  of  concern  for  central  and  state 
10. 
governments,  considering  that  their  losses  have  reached  an  alarming  level  of  Rs330  billion, 
which is equivalent to about 1.5% of gross domestic product. The accumulation of outstanding 
dues to the central power utilities such as National Thermal Power Corporation, National Hydro 
Power  Corporation,  and  POWERGRID  has  grown  to  over  Rs400  billion.  Thus,  poor  credit 
worthiness  of  SEBs  has  considerably  slowed  private  sector  investments,  despite  the  central 
Government’s  enabling  and  encouraging  framework.  Consequently,  the  Government  has 
formulated  the  Accelerated  Power  Development  and  Reform  Program  to  bring  the  reforms  to 
the  distribution  level  with  an  overall  objective  of  reducing  T&D  losses  to  15%.  The  Ministry  of 
Power has signed agreements with 24 states to expedite the process of reforms under program 
incentives.  The  agreements  provide  for  metering  of  all  11  kV  feeders,  100%  metering  of 
consumers,  energy  audit,  reduction  of  T&D  losses,  and  attaining  commercial  viability  of 
distribution. 
 
11. 
SEBs  will  have  to  fund  corresponding  strengthening  and  expansion  of  their  own  state 
transmission  and  distribution  networks  if  they  are  to  reap  the  full  benefits  of  investments  in 
additional  generation  capacity,  and  strengthening and expansion of the national transmission 
grid.  Unless  reforms  are  undertaken  by  SEBs  in  a  timely  manner  to  improve  their  financial 
sustainability, inadequate state transmission and distribution facilities may continue to constrain 
economic growth and hamper electricity access to all households by 2012. 
 
12.

requisite statutory powers to promote and enforce a progressive regime of energy conservation. 
The  10th  Plan  targets  energy  saving  of  95,000  GWh,  mainly  from  the  industry  and  agriculture 
sectors using energy efficient equipment.

The  proposed  Power  Grid  Transmission  (Sector)  Project  involves  strengthening  and  expansion  of  the  national 
transmission grid. In accordance with the sector lending procedure of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), three core 
subprojects identified in the southern regional grid involve setting up of five new substations in two states of Andhra

expansion of the transmission systems of the Power Grid Corporation of India Limited (POWERGRID) is expected to 
reduce  system  losses,  which  in  turn  will  improve  frequency  and  voltage  levels,  and  ultimately  reduce  wear  on 
electrical  equipment.  This  will  lead  to  more  efficient  use  of  resources  and  make  more  power  available  to  increase 
electrification  outreach.  In  addition,  it  will  facilitate  efficient  utilization  of  existing  and  planned  power  plants.  The 
strengthening of the sector in the selected states will result in efficient delivery of services to consumers. Profitability 
and efficiency in the farm and nonfarm sector is expected to improve with improvements in quality and reliability of 
power  supply  with  effective  restructuring.  For  the  poor,  wage  employm ent  opportunities  and  farm  profitability  and 
household welfare will improve.  

 
B.         Poverty Analysis                                                   Targeting Classification: General intervention     
 
The  three  core  subprojects  cover  five  districts  in  the  two  states  of  Andhra  Pradesh  and  Tamil  Nadu,  and  Union 
Territory  of  Pondicherry.  These  states  are  among  the  better-off states in the country in terms of per capita income, 
economic growth, and human and social development. In case of Andhra Prades h, the National Human Development 
Report (2001) ranks the state as 10th among 15 states calculated. Poverty is still a pertinent problem in the state with 
15.77%  of  the  state  population  living  below  the  poverty  line  (1999/00)  compared  with  national  data  of 26.10%. The 
state of Tamil Nadu, on the other hand, is country's 6th most populous state, and was ranked it 3rd out of 15 states 
calculated. In general, the state has been successful in its overall efforts to address poverty, and the proportion of 
those  living  below  the  poverty  line  fell  from  over  35.03%  in  1993/94  to  21.12%  in  1999/00.  The  state  ranks  12th in 
human poverty index ranking for the country.  
 
Poverty levels in the Union Territory of Pondicherry were estimated at 37.40%( 1993/94) and 21.67% (1999/00). In all 
the three states, poverty levels are now largely lower than the national average. However, in spite of this impressive 
performance, poverty remains pervasive with a large section of the population (scheduled castes/tribes, minorities, 
women) not benefiting from the economic and social development. 
 
The Project is expected to result in efficient delivery of services to consumers. The improved frequency and voltage as 
will boost the industry and agriculture sectors leading to enhanced production, and improved economic development.  
 
 
C.         Participation Process 

 

 
During project preparation, a total of 10 consultations and meetings with the project communities in the five subproject 
districts were organized. Discussions aimed at ascertaining community response to the subprojects, their needs and 
demands from the subprojects, an estimate of losses that they would suffer, and steps to mitigate those losses. These 
meetings  were  held  in  groups  comprising  village  panchayats,  village  administrative officers, men, women, farmers, 
and disadvantaged groups to ensure a comprehensive perspective on the Project and its impacts.

Based  on  the  premise  that  no  development  activity  can  be  gender  neutral  and  potentially  affects  women, gender

benefits that should boost industrial development and agricultural production (by making available options of irrigation

The financial internal rate of return (FIRR) compares the annual streams of financial capital and

2. 
The  main  benefits  stems  from  (i)  removing  existing  bottlenecks  to  meet  the  growing 
energy  needs  by  introducing  economic  dispatch  between  neighboring  regions;  (ii)  improving 
efficiency  reliability  and  system  security;  (iii)  facilitating  energy  trade  from  surplus  to  deficit 
regions;  and  (iv)  reducing  losses.  The  physical  output—interstate  transmission  of  electricity—
will  add  to  existing  supply  (incremental  benefit)  and  will  substitute  (nonincremental)  for 
alternative  forms  of  energy  supply.  The  incremental  benefit  of  the  interregional  link  of  22,000 
megawatts (MW) is about 102,000 gigawatt-hours (GWh) of electricity transmission at 60% load 
factor. The incremental benefits were valued for each category of customers, using customers’ 
willingness to pay for electricity. 
 
3. 
The nonincremental benefit was quantified using the alternative energy resources used 
in  the  without-project  scenario.  The  16,000  MW  of  demand  not  met  (23,500  GWh  assuming  4

alternative energy sources—kerosene, lamp, diesel irrigation pump, and diesel generation—for 
respective  customer  class.  The  nonincremental  benefits  were  divided  to  customer  categories 
using  the  approximate  pattern  of  load-shedding  by  the  customer  class:  domestic  (55%), 
commercial (10%), industrial (20%), and agriculture (15%).
